<<<api>>>: StringTokenizer.nextToken
<<<code>>>: public class TokenizerMapper extends Mapper<Object, Text, Text, IntWritable> {
```java
    private final static IntWritable one = new IntWritable(1);
    private Text count = new Text();

    public void map(Object key, Text value, Context context) throws IOException, InterruptedException {
        StringTokenizer itr = new StringTokenizer(value.toString());
        itr.nextToken(); // Skip over first line, which has just one element
        while (itr.hasMoreTokens()) {
            itr.nextToken(); // Skip over word
            count.set(itr.nextToken()); // save count as key
            context.write(count, one);
        }
    }
}
```
<<<explanation>>>: The issue with the code is that the `nextToken()` method of the `StringTokenizer` class is throwing a `NoSuchElementException` when it reaches the end of the input string. This is because the `nextToken()` method returns `null` when it reaches the end of the input string and not a token. To fix this issue, you can use the `hasMoreTokens()` method to check if there are more tokens to be read before calling `nextToken()`.

In the `map()` method of the `TokenizerMapper` class, you can use a `while` loop to read the tokens from the input string. Inside the loop, you can call `nextToken()` to read the next token, `hasMoreTokens()` to check if there are more tokens to be read, and `set()` to save the count as the key. Finally, you can call `write()` to write the key-value pair to the output.
